Introduction to HTML.HTML: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language for creating web pages. It uses a system of tags to define the structure and layout of a webpage. HTML provides the foundation for web development, allowing developers to structure text, images, links, multimedia, and more.

1_Basic_Structure_of_HTML_Document.Code:
Welcome to HTML

This is a paragraph.

Explanation.DOCTYPE: Declares the document as HTML5, ensuring compatibility with modern browsers and standards.
Explanation.html: The root element of the HTML document that encompasses all other elements.
Explanation.head: Contains metadata, links to stylesheets, scripts, and other resources that do not appear directly on the webpage.
Explanation.body: Contains the visible content of the webpage, such as text, images, and interactive elements.

Headings.Explanation: Headings are used to define the hierarchy and structure of content. They range from <h1> (highest level) to <h6> (lowest level).

Paragraphs.Explanation: Paragraph tags are used to structure text into blocks for better readability.

Links.Explanation: Anchor tags (<a>) create hyperlinks, allowing navigation to other web pages or resources.

Attributes.src: Specifies the path to the image file.
Attributes.alt: Provides alternative text for accessibility and in case the image fails to load.
Attributes.width: Defines the width of the image in pixels or percentage.

Unordered_List.Explanation: Unordered lists are used to group items without implying a specific order. Items are typically displayed with bullet points.

Ordered_List.Explanation: Ordered lists are used to present items in a sequence, often numbered or alphabetized.

3_Attributes.Explanation: Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements. They are specified inside the opening tag and follow a name="value" format. Attributes enhance the behavior and functionality of elements.

Details.href: Specifies the URL the link points to.
Details.target: Determines where to open the linked document. _blank opens it in a new tab or window.

4_HTML_Forms.Code:
<form action="/submit" method="post">
  <label for="name">Name:</label>
  <input type="text" id="name" name="name">
  
  <label for="email">Email:</label>
  <input type="email" id="email" name="email">

  <input type="submit" value="Submit">
</form>

Explanation.form: The container for all form elements, used to collect user input.
Explanation.action: Specifies the URL where form data should be submitted.
Explanation.method: Defines the HTTP method (GET or POST) used to send data.
Explanation.input: Represents a field for user input. It can have various types such as text, email, password, or submit.

Explanation.table: Creates a table to organize data into rows and columns.
Explanation.th: Represents a header cell in a table.
Explanation.td: Represents a standard data cell in a table.

6_HTML_Semantic_Elements.Explanation: Semantic elements convey the meaning of the content within the tags. These elements improve accessibility, SEO, and readability for developers.

Examples.header: Defines the header section of a page, often containing logos or navigation links.
Examples.footer: Defines the footer section of a page, often containing copyright or contact information.
Examples.article: Represents a self-contained piece of content, such as a blog post or news article.
Examples.section: Groups related content, such as a chapter or section of a document.

Adding_Videos.Code:
<video width="320" height="240" controls>
  <source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
Adding_Videos.Explanation: The <video> tag embeds a video player in the webpage. The <source> tag specifies the video file and format.

Adding_Audio.Code:
<audio controls>
  <source src="audio.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>
Adding_Audio.Explanation: The <audio> tag embeds an audio player in the webpage. The <source> tag specifies the audio file and format.

8_HTML_Comments.Explanation: Comments in HTML are used to include notes or documentation for developers. They are not displayed on the webpage.

HTML_Entities.Explanation: HTML entities are used to display reserved characters or symbols that would otherwise be interpreted as code.

10_Practice_Tips: Write HTML code in a simple text editor or an IDE like VS Code for syntax highlighting and auto-completion.
Use proper indentation to organize nested elements and enhance readability.
Experiment with various tags, attributes, and properties to build versatile web pages.
Regularly validate your HTML using tools like the W3C Markup Validation Service to ensure compliance with standards.
